DOCNAME: CASE OF STRAIN AND OTHERS v. ROMANIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of P1-1;Violation of Art. 6-1 concerning the reasonable time;Inadmissible under Art. 6-1 concerning the others complaints;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE respectively . The first lives in GPE , the second in GPE ( GPE ) and the others in GPE .

CARDINAL . The first CARDINAL applicants and their deceased brother , PERSON , whose heirs are the other CARDINAL applicants , were the owners of a house in GPE . In DATE the ORG took possession of that house under Decree no . ORG on nationalisation . The house was converted into CARDINAL flats intended for rental .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first CARDINAL applicants and PERSON brought an action for the recovery of possession of immovable property in ORG against ORG and NORP , a ORG - owned company responsible for the management of property belonging to the ORG . After the death of PERSON , the action was pursued by his heirs , PERSON and PERSON . The applicants sought a declaration that they were the rightful owners of the house and appurtenant land that the ORG had , in their opinion , wrongfully seized in DATE . They claimed that , under LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , property belonging to persons in certain social categories was not subject to nationalisation , and that they fell within such a category . In their view , the nationalisation of the house in question had therefore been improper and unlawful .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG Instance dismissed the applicants ' action , refusing to rule on the merits on the ground that they could not obtain redress for the damage they had sustained until the enactment of special legislation introducing reparation measures . The judgment was upheld by ORG on DATE . The applicants appealed against that decision .

CARDINAL . In DATE the tenants of the flats making up the house applied to purchase them , relying on Law no . CARDINAL . ORG informed the NORP company that a dispute was pending concerning the title to the house and instructed it not to pursue the sale of the flats in question .

CARDINAL . Consequently , the tenants of CARDINAL flats had their purchase applications rejected , but not PERSON ( a former football player and international celebrity ) and his wife , to whom the NORP company sold flat CARDINAL on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld an appeal by the applicants and remitted the case to ORG for a decision on the merits .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr and PERSON applied to intervene in ORG proceedings on the ground that they had been the owners of flat no . CARDINAL since its sale on DATE .

CARDINAL . Further to the couple 's application to intervene , the applicants requested the court to find that the sale of flat no . CARDINAL was null and void . In their view , as the nationalisation had been improper and unlawful , the ORG could not have been the rightful owner of the property and thus could not lawfully have sold any part of it . The applicants relied in particular on LAW , whereby an undertaking entered into on an erroneous or unlawful basis could not produce any useful effect .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held that the nationalisation of the house had been unlawful and that the applicants were therefore the rightful owners . However , the court rejected the request for the rescission of the contract of sale between the ORG and PERSON and PERSON , on the ground that the couple had made the purchase in good faith .
CARDINAL . The applicants appealed against that judgment . On DATE ORG allowed the appeal and remitted the case to ORG for reconsideration .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG held that the nationalisation of the house had been unlawful , that the applicants were the rightful owners and that the contract of sale between the ORG and PERSON and PERSON was null and void .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG allowed an appeal by PERSON and PERSON and dismissed the applicants ' action , finding that the nationalisation had been lawful and that , consequently , the sale by the ORG of flat no . CARDINAL was also lawful .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed to ORG , which gave its judgment on DATE . It partly allowed the applicants ' appeal in so far as it found the nationalisation to have been unlawful and acknowledged that they had remained the rightful owners of the property . However , it dismissed the appeal as regards the rescission of the sale of flat no . CARDINAL , considering that the ORG had been presumed to be the owner of the property at the time of the sale , in spite of the dispute over the property that was pending in the courts . It moreover relied on the fact that PERSON no . LANGUAGE , which had formed the statutory basis for the sale of the property , did not provide for any penalty in respect of property sold when the title to it was in dispute before the courts . ORG did not address the applicants ' argument relating to the principle of unjust enrichment ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants again requested ORG to order the rescission of the sale of flat no . CARDINAL , contending that the purchasers had broken the law . Their action was dismissed on DATE on the ground that the matter had become res judicata .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on the nationalisation of certain immovable property are as follows :

“ ... in order to ensure the proper management of dwellings which wealthy capitalists and exploiters who possess a large number of properties have allowed to fall into dilapidation as a means of sabotage ; [ and ]
In order to deprive exploiters of an important means of exploitation ;
The immovable property appearing in the schedules ... annexed to and forming part of this Decree shall be nationalised . The listed property comprises :

( CARDINAL ) immovable property belonging to former industrialists , owners of large estates , bankers , owners of large trading enterprises and other representatives of the wealthy capitalist class ;
( CARDINAL ) immovable property belonging to real - estate exploiters ... ”

“ The immovable property of workers , civil servants , small artisans , persons working in intellectual professions and retired persons shall be excluded from the scope of this Decree and shall not be nationalised . ”

“ Individuals who formerly owned residential property which passed lawfully into the ownership of the ORG or of another artificial person after DATE and which was still in the possession of the ORG or another artificial person on DATE shall be entitled to benefit , by way of reparation , from the measures in this PERSON .
The provisions of this PERSON shall apply equally to the successors in title of such former owners , subject to existing statutory provisions . ”

“ The persons referred to in LAW shall be entitled to restitution in the form of the restoration to them of their ownership of flats in which they currently live as tenants or which are vacant . In respect of other flats , those persons shall receive compensation as provided in LAW ”

“ The tenants of flats which are not returned to the former owners or their successors in title [ in accordance with the procedure laid down in this PERSON ] may opt , after the expiry of the period provided for in section CARDINAL , to purchase such flats by payment in full or in instalments .
“ Persons entitled to claim restitution or compensation shall lodge an application for such purpose within DATE after this PERSON comes into force . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government adopted decision no . CARDINAL implementing PERSON no . DATE . The decision provided that immovable property that had passed into ORG ownership under a legislative provision was to be regarded as immovable property legally vested in the ORG . It also specified that PERSON no . DATE did not apply to immovable property held by the State where its right of property was not based on any legislative provision .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Government adopted decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , supplementing decision no . CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of decision no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL provided that , in order for property to be defined as having been acquired by ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , it had to have been acquired in accordance with the decree and the person referred to as the owner in the lists enumerating nationalised property had to have been the true owner at the time of the nationalisation .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of Law no . CARDINAL of DATE on the rules governing immovable property wrongfully seized by the ORG DATE and DATE read as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG property wrongfully seized by the State ... DATE and DATE and property expropriated under LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) that has not been returned shall be subject to restitution , normally consisting of the return of the property in question ...

( CARDINAL ) Where the property can not be returned , alternative measures of redress shall be taken . Such measures may consist of compensation in the form of other items or services ... , the allotment of shares in commercial companies listed on the stock market , securities at face value used exclusively in the privatisation process or pecuniary compensation . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) Within DATE after the entry into force of the present Law , the claimant shall serve notice on the artificial person in possession of the property and seek the return of that property ... ”
Section CARDINAL

“ A special law shall be enacted within DATE of the expiry of the DATE period fixed for the service of notice . That law , on the basis of the estimates , shall provide for the payment of compensation , stipulating the conditions , amounts and procedures and possibly fixing a ceiling . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) The sale or donation of immovable property unlawfully seized by the ORG shall be declared null and void , save where such transactions were entered into in good faith .
CARDINAL . NORP The relevant provisions of LAW no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL on land registers read as follows :

“ Rights in rem vested in immovable property may be acquired if it is so agreed between vendor and purchaser and if the corresponding creation or conveyance of such a right is entered in the land register . ”

“ Rights in rem shall be acquired without being entered in the land register by means of succession , accession , sale in execution or expropriation ; however , the holder of the right shall have the capacity to alienate his or her property , by virtue of the land register , only after the right has been entered therein . ”

“ Save in respect of statutory restrictions or exceptions , the entries in the land register shall be regarded as correct for the benefit of the person who has acquired a right in rem through a legal transaction for valuable consideration if , at the time the right was acquired , the land register did not mention any action whereby the information therein might be challenged or if the person concerned has not , in any other manner , become aware of an inaccuracy . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Civil Code reads :
“ An obligation without legal basis or based on an erroneous or unlawful ground can not produce any useful effect . ”

CARDINAL . Under NORP law , an action for recovery of possession is one of the principal remedies for the protection of a right of property . Such action is not governed per se by statute but has emerged from case - law . An action for recovery of possession can be defined as the bringing of proceedings to enforce a right in rem in which a dispossessed owner claims back his or her property from the person currently in possession of it . The main outcome of such an action , if successful , is the acknowledgment by the court of the claimant 's title to the property , with retrospective effect , thus obliging the defendant to return the property . If physical restitution is no longer possible , that obligation is replaced by an obligation to pay compensation on the basis of an equivalent sum ( see , for example , PERSON , ORG şi dezmembrămintele sale ( Ownership and its Attributes ) , PERSON , ORG , pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL , and PERSON and PERSON , Elementele dreptului civil , vol . CARDINAL , NORP reale ( Elements of Civil Law , vol . CARDINAL , Rights in rem ) , GPE DATE , p. CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In legal systems derived from NORP law there is an equitable rule that when a person has been unjustly enriched at the expense of another , the latter may claim compensation in the amount by which that person has been enriched ( see PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , Droit civil : les obligations ( Civil Law : Obligations ) , ORG , CARDINALth edition , DATE , pp . DATE , and PERSON , ORG civil : PERSON generală a obligaţiilor ( Civil Law : General theory of obligations ) , PERSON , GPE DATE , p. CARDINAL ) . Whilst an action for tortious liability enables the injured party to claim exact reparation for the loss sustained as a result of negligence on the part of an enriched person , in an action for unjust enrichment the claimant can only seek an amount corresponding to the other party 's gain , provided that some pecuniary benefit has been obtained , without just cause , at the expense of the claimant ( see GPE , PERSON and GPE , op . cit . , p. CARDINAL , and PERSON , op . cit . , p. CARDINAL ) .
